image.altText: Fighters of Wagner private mercenary group pose for a picture.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: UK to declare Russia's Wagner Group a terrorist organisation. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Russia's Wagner mercenary group will be declared a terrorist group by the UK government. That means it will be illegal to be a member or support the organisation. The UK's Home Secretary Suella Braverman says Wagner is " violent and destructive … a military tool of Vladimir Putin's Russia." Wagner played a key role in Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and its fighters have been accused of killing and torturing Ukrainian citizens. It's estimated that they've operated in some 30 different countries, including Syria and parts of Africa. You can read more about the group and how it started here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UK to declare Wagner mercenary group a terrorist organisation

featuredLink.title: What do we know about the Wagner group, the Russian militia whose leader is believed dead in a plane crash?

children.content: Wagner fighters work for money rather than a particular country or cause.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Holly Richardson Two Russians and a French citizen have been rescued from the Coral Sea, 835 kilometres, south-east of Cairns, after their inflatable catamaran began sinking. The nine-metre boat was on its way from Vanuatu to Cairns when both hulls were damaged in several shark attacks. The group activated an emergency beacon at 1:30am, and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority requested the assistance of a nearby vehicle carrier along with the Cairns-based Challenger Rescue Aircraft. The vehicle carrier, Dugong Ace, collected the group. They are due to arrive in Brisbane on Thursday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Three people rescued after inflatable boat attacked by sharks in Coral Sea

children.content: The crew were travelling on a nine-metre inflatable catamaran.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Patrick Bell Federal ministers are adamant there is no need for a review of the government's decision to reject Qatar Airways' application for more flights to major Australian airports. That is despite the Senate voting to hold an inquiry into the decision, and revelations the prime minister was unaware exactly when Transport Minister Catherine King signed off on the decision. In Question Time yesterday, Anthony Albanese said he had spoken to Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka, whose airline codeshares with Qatar, before the application was rejected, but insisted he did not have a conversation with former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce. You can read the rest of the story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government has 'no intention' to review Qatar Airways decision

featuredLink.title: 'No intention' to review Qatar Airways decision despite Senate inquiry

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data shows an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy grows by 2.1 per cent in 12 months, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm so glad you asked, because the ABS has helpfully distilled it into 11 key takeaways. I won't hit you with them all at once, but here's the first few that mention some terms you'll be familiar with: Inflation continued to moderate. The consumer price index rose 0.8 per cent in the June quarter and was up 6.0 per cent in the past 12 months. This marked the second consecutive quarter of lower annual inflation, down from the peak of 7.8 per cent in the December 2022 quarter. Food prices increased 1.6 per cent during the quarter, and housing costs as measured in the CPI rose 0.8 per cent. Higher interest rates squeezed consumption. Households shelled out $82.8 billion in mortgage interest payable during the year. This was almost double last year’s interest bill. Discretionary household spending fell 0.5 per cent in the June quarter, which was the third quarterly fall in a row. Spending on furnishings and household equipment fell for the fifth quarter in succession, down 3.4 per cent in annual terms. Retail sales fell 0.5 per cent during the quarter, and retail inventories fell sharply. We worked more hours. We spent 2.4 per cent more time at work than we did last quarter, which, excluding the COVID-19 pandemic, was the fastest quarterly increase in hours worked on record. We worked 6.8 per cent more hours this year than last year, and with GDP rising by a smaller amount, labour productivity fell 3.2 per cent in annual terms.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happened in the Australian economy in the three months to June?

children.content: I'm so glad you asked, because the ABS has helpfully distilled it into 11 key takeaways.
I won't hit you with them all at once, but here's the first few that mention some terms you'll be familiar with:
. The consumer price index rose 0.8 per cent

in the June quarter and was up 6.0 per cent in the past 12 months. This marked the second consecutive quarter of lower annual inflation, down from the peak of 7.8 per cent in the December 2022 quarter. Food prices increased 1.6 per cent during the quarter, and housing costs as measured in the CPI rose 0.8 per cent.

. Households shelled out $82.8 billion in mortgage interest payable during the year. This was almost double last year’s interest bill. Discretionary household spending fell 0.5 per cent in the June quarter, which was the third quarterly fall in a row. Spending on furnishings and household equipment fell for the fifth quarter in succession, down 3.4 per cent in annual terms. Retail sales fell 0.5 per cent during the quarter, and retail inventories fell sharply.

. We spent 2.4 per cent more time at work than we did last quarter, which, excluding the COVID-19 pandemic, was the fastest quarterly increase in hours worked on record. We worked 6.8 per cent more hours this year than last year, and with GDP rising by a smaller amount, labour productivity fell 3.2 per cent in annual terms.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's economy expanded by 0.4 per cent over from April to June and by 2.1 per cent over the year on a seasonally adjusted basis. Decreased household spending weighed on the economy. The Bureau of Statistics says capital investment and tourism drove the economy as the number of international students and tourists returned to Australia. Economists had predicted that the economy would expand by 0.3 per cent over the June quarter, and by 1.8 per cent over the year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economy expands by 0.4 per cent over June quarter

children.content: Australia's economy expanded by 0.4 per cent over from April to June and by 2.1 per cent over the year on a seasonally adjusted basis.
Decreased household spending weighed on the economy.
The Bureau of Statistics says capital investment and tourism drove the economy as the number of international students and tourists returned to Australia.
Economists had predicted that the economy would expand by 0.3 per cent over the June quarter, and by 1.8 per cent over the year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The New South Wales government will increase coal royalty rates next year to boost revenue from coal resources. From July, the rate will rise 2.6 per cent, replacing the emergency coal cap brought in by the previous government in December. The new scheme will deliver a $2.7 billion dollar boost to the budget over four years. NSW Treasurer Daniel Mookhey insists the increase won't drive up household power bills, even though coal producers will face higher costs. "And we are ploughing back every single dollar into rebuilding the state's essential services and providing families with much needed cost of living relief." Mr Mookhey says the decision to raise coal royalties comes after extensive consultations. "We think we've got the balance right." "We are updating these royalty rates to make sure the people of New South Wales get a fair return for their resources."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW increases coal royalties

children.content: The New South Wales government will increase coal royalty rates next year to boost revenue from coal resources.
From July, the rate will rise 2.6 per cent, replacing the emergency coal cap brought in by the previous government in December.
The new scheme will deliver a $2.7 billion dollar boost to the budget over four years.
NSW Treasurer Daniel Mookhey insists the increase won't drive up household power bills, even though coal producers will face higher costs.
"And we are ploughing back every single dollar into rebuilding the state's essential services and providing families with much needed cost of living relief."
Mr Mookhey says the decision to raise coal royalties comes after extensive consultations.
"We think we've got the balance right."
"We are updating these royalty rates to make sure the people of New South Wales get a fair return for their resources."
